1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
0
Non recommand√©
2.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 27 juin 2020
Preface: I have very little time in this game. I was worried about loosing my chance to refund it if I lingered. I passed through the first dungeon and reviewed my 3rd party member (the fighter) before deciding to stop.

Summary: While the characters, setting and world were interesting, the gameplay itself was underwhelming.

The characters I met seemed interesting and I wanted to learn more about them. The artwork, design, and voice acting are good, even great. However, while a game can be beautiful, but if its not fun to play then I don't think of it as a good game.

The talent trees were short and abilities were uninteresting. In combat you have your basic attacks, a "defend" skill that recharges some of your resource bar, and various class skills that spend your resource. The Skills have some variety in what they can do, but there are too few to make what feels like a character with a sort of theme. Also the term "skill tree" implies branching paths of options. This game does not offer that. Each of the three "trees" a class has is a single linear path of 3-4 skills that have passives that are bland stat boosts.

Another complaint is the character builder at the start has a "race" option that is really just an illusion of customization. You have 4 options, each which is good for a specific class, and one that gives a small boost to all stats. So for each class you can choose between the "ideal" race that most benefits your class choice (intellect for a wizard, dex for a ranged, strength for melee), the "jack of all trades" race which is a weird thing to include in a game where there is little felxibility in character builds, or one of the 2 other races that don't give you any stats of value for your class.

I think this could be a great game with a rework of the talent system. However as it stands I don't find it fun to play.
 
FatMoses
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0

√âvaluation publi√©e le 12 juillet 2021
Operencia was a good ride. It's the most modernized dungeon crawler RPG out there. The game was beyond well-polished with a lot of skills/items/characters combos. I'd recommended anyone with RPG experience to start the game with harder monster difficulty. The puzzles and secrets were good and sometimes a bit too extreme, you may need to google here and there so that you can continue instead of giving up the game completely. The game will satisfy any RPG hardcore and most of you who interested in RPG out there.
 
Ivalice

2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

Recommand√©
30.4 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 22 d√©cembre 2020
I love these RPG's that allow backtracking to the point where nothing is missable; so good! The tile-based movement is also really nice, but some people may not like it.

If you're worried about running out of wood, at the end of some dungeon levels, there are doors that take you to the next dungeon level. Each time you get low health, just travel back to that dungeon and use that door to get a full heal. (Example: There's a Portal at the end of one level.)
 
Hemlock

√âvaluation publi√©e le 13 octobre 2020
Combat is uninspiring and too dependent on special abilities rather than normal attacks, which results in mana depletion and a need to rest often.

The characters and the narrator just do not stop talking. You can't pull a lever, explore a room, find a puzzle or make an attack without a jest, a remark or a lore explanation.

I wish it was more like Grimrock.

It's not bad, but it's hard to say if the bad will outweigh the good for others on this one. It did for me though.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 4 avril 2021
Beware: This is not a VR game, it's a regular game with poorly implemented VR support, you can't even fully see the interface and the graphics look pretty awful seen from up close. So if it's just a regular game, i'd rather play it without VR and if i'm going to play a regular dungeon crawler, i'd rather play more of Legend of Grimrock or Bard's tale. I haven't seen much of this one but at first glance it really didn't seem like something i'd spend hours in.

1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
1
Recommand√©
46.0 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 29 juillet 2020
I feel conflicted writing a review to this.
First of all, if there would be an middle thumb I totally would give it, but since recommendations on steam are binary I had to choose or I had to shut up, all in all the game wasn't that much bad to justify a thumbs down I suppose.

The game has as many flaws as it has strenths. Graphically it may be the most impressive First-Person Dungeon Crawler I have played so far, great lighting imaganitive locations, it's like a dark fairytale.
The characters are lovely, even when you never explore them too well. It's pretty on the surface regarding interpersonal communication and characters like Josk√° and Mezey were written with a clear dynamic in mind which is explored in lots of tropes yet, but they're able to entertain the player even if you can't take them too serious. There are some plot twists towards that make the story more interesting, which is something the game pretty much lacks for most of the time and interesting narrative. I have to appreciate that somehow all you experience between the several locations is somehow interconnected, sometimes a bit too well, but in the end you play a pretty classical hero tale from start to finish, where your goal consists of salvage a sword for most of the time. There is one minor antagonist that keeps reappearing but overall there is not much surprise going on until the end, which can draw the motivation form the player if you aren't that much invested in the gameplay which focus shifts more and more towards the repetetive combat the further you progess.

The turn based combat is simplistic but fast paced but I have to lie if I would say it never overstayed it's welcome. The problem is that it lacks depth on many ocassions starting with the illusion of character customization. After the intro you're asked to create your own character out of a few preset portraits, you can choose 3 classes and set attributes as well an permanent perk, but all of it is already layed out so that you're not really have much options unless you go for something totally stupid like an mage who has invested a lot of points in strength.
Unlike in other First Person CRPG's like that, your avatar has an set personality and voice lines. I see no reason why they couldn't come up with an original design ditchting the customization part at all. I suppose you somehow have expectations in that genre that you need to fulfill even when it really not fits the narrative. In that case the game pretends to have more depth than there actually is and this translates to many ocassions.
While you have a lot of equipment in the game and 3 skill trees you there is little you can do to prepare for the inevitable battles, so there are a lots of enemies that can inflict status effects to you, a lot of them make you lose control over your own characters, usually and typical JRPG's you're able to hold against it with items, like as long you're still in control of one of your characters you are slowly able to regain the control. This is hardly possible in this game. There is nothing that helps you to protect from said status effects. There are some skills that allow you to remove them but every skill in the game has cooldowns, so you can use them only once for x turns. That doesn't really help when later enemy groups conists of 5 enemies where 3 of them keep reapplying a "panic" effect where you're characters randomly attack eachother. The only thing that allowed me to survive these encounter is retrying until the RNG was in my favor and there is a loooot RNG, the outcome of the battle can drastically change and quickly become very onesided, this is something where I lost several times my faith on the game that tactics really matter.
I have to admit that I played on the hardest settings possible except for permadeath (which is stupid in such an long and RNG-heavy game) so I suppose if you play it just normally you might not encounter the same issues, but then it suppose it generally becomes to easy since there is a lack of variety in enemy design.
So there are overall 12 locations in the game, but for every location you may encounter only 1 or 2 enemy types, one of the worst offenders here is the "copper forest" where you encounter just the one and only enemy type over and over again. This enemy can draw out all your magic and there is little you can do to prevent it, so all you do is becoming more ressourceful in not refilling your energy as far as you could and spamming instant-kill at the beginning or normal attacks if this ain't workin because of bad RNG. Enemy groups are organzied and you encounter most of the time the same formation of tanks that redirect attacks, casters that summon and inflict a lot of damage and or "DMG" in the back or front row. The formation system, where you inflict different damage on different lanes on the field compensates for that at the beginning with seemlingly interesting choices, but it gets too old too fast, in the the end the approach stays the game from the beginning to the end.
There are also minor annoyances that I would call "design oversights" so for example your party is predetermined and consists of all kind of class archtypes... except mages, so if you wanna go wild with spells, well you better have chosen a mage at the beginning or you have to deal with something half assed like Csilla (priest) or Kela (supporter)
You also start the game with an character who is specialised in inflicting poison. Too bad that for the first three dungeons almost every enemy is immune or resistant to poison which renders this character pretty much useless for most of the time, you instead builing up his strengths you literally end up spending all his points in strength, because he becomes way more useful as an simple dmg dealer. Status effects overall seem to be only useful on the enemy side. There is one effect that is highly useful (silencing), everything else you can't apply to 90% of all enemy types, you better not spending points in useless skills like "sleep" or "charming". On the other hand, you can build up a high resistance to poison, but in the end after the second location, no enemy ever inflicts you with poison again, this is totally ridicilous, at the point you finally have a good resistance to poison, you no longer need it.

Despite beeing a dungeon crawler there are a lot of convenicence option, like gaining exp even for deceased characters and getting fully healed when reaching a new level. These weren't necesarry in my opinion but I suppose they are were decided you can't run in a booby trap since enemies in the game are limited, they never respawn. In that fashion you also alllowed to reskill you characters, at every point with no penalty. This is were convenience has gone a little bit too far in my opinion. Allowing yourself to relocate point makes your decisions less impactful in best case you just redesign your party for every encounter in the best way possible (and even then you're not having that much options) in the end the skill tree's are so minmal you end up with having all skills and most of the passive stats bonuses anyway. Planning ahead does not longer feel rewarding if you can correct mistakes at any time.

There is a lot of puzzle solving at the beginning but later in the game it becomes overshadowed by too much lengthy combat. Also the puzzle design is sometimes clever enough but sometimes questionable. It's these kind of puzzles were you do get not much hints and have to recognize a pattern for you own. So at one point you have to light light candles in a certain layout, but how do I know which candles to light up? Well look at the ceiling there is a pattern above. So the solutions doesn't require much deduction, it's just you have to stumble on the solution by accident
"Relics" are also just contextualized actions pretending to be a feature like items in Zelda, another example for pretending depth.

Reached maximum text size ok i'm done! xd
 
Chocos Ramabotti

Aber sonst: Schaut toll aus (HP Reverb G2) und steuert sich befriedigend. Vorteil bei Roomscale: Mir sind die Gegner etwas zu nah dran, da rolle ich einfach etwas zur√ºck, passt schon!

√âvaluation publi√©e le 31 mai 2020
This is just a fantastic old-school dungeon crawler / blobber!!! Party based, grid movement, secrets to find, puzzles to solve, turn based combat, it just checks all the boxes for any fan of blobbers!! I had an incredibly fun time from start to finish and would buy a sequel today if I could. Great lore/story and the art style of the game is amazing....just a beautiful looking game and I'm not one to care about graphics (I enjoyed Legends of Amberland for example).

I started as a hunter, but restarted with a mage in the 2nd area. Playing without your main as a mage from the start would certainly be a different/harder experience. The final fight...wow. lol It was a fun one even though I never even had a scare during it.

My new favorite of the current generation blobbers, beating out The Fall of the Dungeon Guardians that I loved as well. Sequel please!!....because I watched all of the credits. ;)

Cuando apareci√≥ en Steam lo compr√© y debo decir que me encant√≥. Les dejo mi video review donde doy mi opini√≥n ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• los puntos a favor y en contra del Operencia, luego de haberlo terminado.

Recommand√©
70.6 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 28 aout 2022
The environments are stunning, the character progression satisfying, the adversaries often challenging, and the story is well fleshed out. There's a lot to explore and the lore is rich, interesting and engaging. And sometimes the writing and dialogue will coax a smirk or a giggle out of you. A great game to sink your time into. 8/10

But...

The game can feel very scripted. There are no randomized encounters, no randomized loot, and every shred of character XP is deliberate and limited. So you are pretty much forced to seek out every encounter in the game and traverse every inch of the terrain, or else your characters will start to suffer. The game will allow you to return to previous levels with new abilities (metroidvania style) and you should be vigilant about doing so, as some of the better gear and XP is gotten through this backtracking.

Although the grid based movement feels out of place and "clunky" at first, the games puzzles and challenges utilize the feature well, and you'll soon understand why the developers went in that direction. Overall, the whole experience is gorgeous, very tight, but quite inflexible.
 
kyle.geddes
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
25.9 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 5 avril 2020
This game is an absolute pleasure to play. It's stunning to look at and the atmosphere and sounds are perfect. The soundtrack is fantastic. The puzzles are clever and there are plenty of secrets to find. Models are all top quality when you are fighting or looking at character portraits and everything is voice acted.. and done very well.

Movement is grid based. It's the old Bard's Tale/Wizardry feel but almost reminds me of the Myst games with how intricate the environments look. Combat is turn based and lasts a while. I was worried the first few battles on how long it was taking to kill a monster, but your party can really hang in a combat. The damage scalling is well done and skills both recharge and cost energy points to use.

You create one character and gain others in your party as you go. But each character progresses the story and adds to it as you go, so it really works well in this game. You do not get a magic user until later in the game though, and not a dedicated mage at that either. So you might consider making one for your character to get the full range of spells in this game, but any class will do. I played with a fighter and am enjoying it regardless.

I haven't run into a single bug or issue at all, the game plays flawless running at max specs. If you are looking for a Grid Based RPG Crawler type game with atmosphere and charm, this is it!
 
Barundar

0
Recommand√©
60.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 15 mars 2023
Was It Good? 3/5
Did I Like It? 3/5

Basically Might&Magic / Legend of Grimrock, just not quite on par. Polished game, functions well, only 1 map bug (returned to a locked chest icon to find the chest unlocked). These games never have a real story and Operencia runs a Hungarian folklore mixed with generic fairy tales, and it is fully voiced, but you have no choices to make. If you've ever played Might&Magic it comes as a shock that you have to stop listen to a story. The characters are also fleshed out, and the voice acting is 90% good (not you Mezey). Also not you Kampo, which is why I never used you in the game. There are Grimrock-type puzzles sprinkled on almost every level, and they are generally good at breaking up the sameness of dungeon-crawling. The 2 real downsides are unbalanced gameplay, and an uncomfortable inventory/skill page setup

Overall the game is relatively easy if you pay attention to your stats and skills. Quite a few skills are useless in certain situations (such as bringing fire spells to fire resistant enemies) but luckily you can reassign attributes and skills at no cost. I tweaked characters stats and skills on every level. Without doing this, enemy difficulty between levels can SEEM to be a massive step up. It helps that there are very few different enemy types per level, and there is no cohesion between different types either.

Bob (he has 10,000 hit points in a game where end level mobs had 250) was easy, but the end boss took me 12 hours over 6 days to defeat. It was the only battle that you had to slow down and plan each turn and hope you won the RNG battle. I only won because the Succubi didn't charm or silence me until halfway through the fight. The main game is fun - the end battle is bloated and so one-sided it was just not fun.

Every enemy group has the initiative on you. They attack first. That is, unless you get behind them to ambush you. Always ambush enemies if you can, it makes all battles 20% easier.

The inventory/skill page setup is unlike most RPGs, as if things are not intuitively in the right place on the screen. You press ‚ÄúI‚Äù on the keyboard and you go into a full party inventory system, while you really want to use the ‚Äúcharacter‚Äù screen so you can compare weapons & armour stats. You never use ‚ÄúI‚Äù. Pressing ‚ÄúC‚Äù doesn't go into the character screen, its ‚ÄúP‚Äù. If you press ‚ÄúI‚Äù and then press ‚ÄúP‚Äù it doesn't switch to the character screen. You have to click the ‚Äúleft‚Äù arrow button. Changing party members also gives you the option to strip all their gear. You always accidentally press YES, then realise and have to remember what combination of gear you had with the character. I stopped changing my party halfway through and used the same 4 characters.

In all, if you like these types of games this is must-buy. But expect Grimrock x 80%. Also, go with mage. Bob is weak to poison. Kampo is useless. Mezey is grim but your most important character. Every level is fun apart from the World Tree. F*** the World Tree.

Was it good? 3/5
Did I enjoy it? 3.5/5
 
mike_2128
0

Non recommand√©
0.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 28 juin 2020
I am an old guy that was very excited about this game. I cut my teeth playing the old Strategic Simulations AD&D games like Pools of Radiance, and Operencia seemed like the realization of my hopes and dreams for those games realized.

I started it up, and played through the prologue. There is clearly a lot of depth here, but I did not find it intuitive. While this is not explained, I now realize you start as max level characters, and use abilities freely, even if they aren't explained well. I actually ended up dying to the "boss", thinking that perhaps that was actually supposed to happen, and because I had not understood how to take care of my party, as you are just expected to figure that out. I had actually gone into the boss fight with everyone at very low health, and the idea of trying to struggle through it again wasn't appealing.

I started again, and didn't play the prologue. Made a mage, lots of points in intellect, because that's how I've learned to play mages in these games for years. Entered the dungeon, cast some spells, quickly found myself out of mana. Spent the next 30mins swinging my sword, missing or being resisted 9/10 times. It immediately felt like a slog, and my reaction after a half hour of play is I should start over, as I have probably already messed this up.

My experience is probably not the typical one. I'm probably just an old dude with overly nostalgic hopes and an expectation of having my hand held in the beginning of a game. I've no doubt many people have and will enjoy this game. I found it frustrating, unintuitive, and laborious.
 
bsocalk

√âvaluation publi√©e le 3 f√©vrier 2023
An enjoyable old school grid based RPG with a relaxing tone, albeit VERY linear, so it sort of acts as a moving novel.

The voice acting is either fantastic or laughably poor with nothing in between, but the story was pleasant and nicely infused with European lore I was unfamiliar with.

One refreshing aspect was the ability to completely rebuild any character at ANY time, so you never have to worry about taking a "dumb" ability early in the game.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 30 novembre 2022
Very marginal recommendation. Only get this at a steam sale.
Graphics are nice. Combat animations are pretty decent.
Battles are the melee/ranged you may have seen before - not much new or interesting here.
I like the character banter. It is possibly the most interesting aspect of the game.
The core game though... Ugh, it can get dull fast... Searching up and down and up and down for a way to advance...
If advancing in the game requires finding that one specific key or whatever *at least* allow me to add comments to the map.
The inventory system is a bit odd too. Not sure why the wheel was remade here.
Seems like a wasted opportunity - a lot of the mechanics are there for a great game but... this is not a great game.
Was NOT played in VR mode.

22 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

Recommand√©
15.7 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 31 mars 2020
Produit re√ßu gratuitement

Full review:
Vid√©o YouTube‚Ñ¢: Operencia: The Stolen Sun (Quick Review) [PC] 
Vues : 3,756
It may have taken over a year, but Operencia has now arrived on Steam. Was it worth the wait? Let's find out in my Operencia: The Stolen Sun review! Join my Discord server!

Written version below!
It may have taken over a year, but Operencia has now arrived on Steam. I remember adding it to my wishlist a long while back, but the game then entered an Epic exclusivity deal, so it wasn't until this past week that I was finally able to check it out. Was it worth the wait? Well, that's debatable. 

So, for those that don't know, Operencia is a first-person dungeon crawler done in the same style as the classics. It's got the turn-based combat, the fantasy aesthetic that dominates the genre, and the movement that's restricted to a grid. However, the camera is done a bit differently here. Instead of being locked to the four directions, you can actually move the camera around freely.

Puzzles/Exploration:
The game takes advantage of this in its numerous puzzles, which range from tedious to just okay. There are some solutions that are immediately obvious, but require a bunch of steps to complete, and then those that are a bit more random. In fact, the randomness of some of the puzzles was a bit annoying at times. From finding very small objects scattered about the map to stepping through a phantom wall that's hard to see, it can often be frustrating if you're going at it without a walkthrough. Of course, it's not all of the puzzles that are like this, but even the better ones are decent at best. Fortunately, as the game goes on, they become less important in favor of the combat.

Combat:
As mentioned previously, the combat is done in a turn-based manner, with party members moving along an action bar dependent on their stats. The game has an extensive skill and ability system that make up the bulk of each character's available moves. There are party buffs, single-target spells, moves that hit all enemies, and a number of other cool abilities. One of my favorites was a gambler ability, which, when activated, targets an enemy with a 50% chance to instantly kill them at the expense of having a 40% chance for my own guy to die in the process.

Otherwise, the combat plays out just like you'd expect from a dungeon crawler. Although there are a lot of abilities and skills that can be learned, the base combat is simple enough that it doesn't ever feel too complex. If anything, the management of equipped items is more complex. If I had to complain, I would say that the lack of animation skipping can make the combat a bit slow at times, but that's more a quality of life issue. The overall combat is nothing special for the genre, but it's not bad either.

Visuals:
However, if it wasn't obvious already, where Operencia really shines is with regards to its presentation. Everything from its graphics, to its animations, to even its 2D artwork is all excellently done and with some pretty high production values. I was very impressed when I loaded up the first dungeon and began wandering around. There was great use of lighting, an incredible amount of detail, and high-res textures all around. This extended into the combat as well, with a decent amount of enemies to fight all with their own unique animations.

Audio:
Then there's the audio side to the game. The soundtrack, while not the best I've heard in the genre, was nice and matched the game's atmosphere well. What really sold the audio though was the game's incredible sound design. While the soundtrack may have matched the atmosphere, the various sound effects and general ambience of the sound design pretty much made that atmosphere. It actually feels like you're wandering through a forest, an underwater castle, or even a dark cave. In fact, I hated exploring spider-infested caves because of how well it managed to capture that atmosphere. It was some excellent production values all around and made the genre feel much more "modern" in a way.

Overall:
Given all of that, I'll give Operencia: The Stolen Sun a light recommendation. While the puzzles can be tedious, the combat and exploration are fun enough that it's at least worth the look if you're a fan of the genre. Granted, they're not the greatest said genre has to offer, but combine that with the excellent presentation and cheesy, yet fun storyline and you have a decent overall package.

Follow my Steam Curator Page for more reviews + videos!
 
cub
6,447 produits enregistr√©s
5
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
1
Recommand√©
2.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 14 juin 2022
Vous connaissez certainement Legend of Grimrock. Ici, m√™mes labyrinthes avec les m√™mes pi√®ces identiques, m√™mes ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• de sacs, m√™mes enigmes et m√™mes aller-retours interminables sans savoir ce qu'on fait ni o√π on va avec des colonies enti√®res de monstres √† combattre en chemin.
On descend toujours plus bas pour affronter des monstres toujours plus gros. Bref, un dungeon crawler basique. La pr√©sentation et l'UI sont tr√®s bien mais le jeu n'a rien d'original.
Les d√©fauts sont les m√™mes que dans tous les jeux de ce type : Les combats trop longs et r√©p√©titifs et les √©nigmes trop abstruses ( Et m√™me absconses pour certaines) usent la patience rapidement.

Modernis√© par rapport √† quoi ? Oui, modernis√© si on compare avec Eye of the beholder ou Anvil of dawn et les autres jeux vieux de plus de 30 ans.
Il est tr√®s bien si on aime le genre, mais si on aime le genre on en a s√ªrement d√©j√† des dizaines √† peu pr√®s identiques alors celui-ci n'a rien de plus impressionnant que les autres.
A vous de voir. Notez que comme tous ses confr√®res il faut beaucoup de patience et de r√©solution pour en voir le bout, donc on n'est pas vol√© sur la quantit√©. Mais ce n'est pas gratifiant.

Il est traduit dans une dizaine de langages barbares et dans aucun langage civilis√©. C'est pour ca que j'√©cris cette √©valuation dans une langue gutturale et primitive, car si vous comprenez c'est que vous √™tes un de ces barbares hirsutes et naus√©abonds et vous comprendrez le jeu. Enfin, je l'esp√®re.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 1 avril 2020
So, have only played a bit, but will certainly continue. This is a good Corona-diversion!

Cool, turn-based RPG. Turn-based is probably because it's a small studio, but they make it work.

Setting is cool, accented english is cool and everything feels fresh. Don't know if the story will turn out to be awesome yet, but it's drawn me enough in that I'm curious. Also, since it's a not a bland big team in the US, I actually don't know what to expect.

Combat seems solid, and the RPG and levels system as well. It's not something I'm going to fuzz over min-maxing though, it's servicable.

One of my favorite game experiences this year, hope in the next hours the game keeps surprising me.

Produit re√ßu gratuitement

Lo he comprado solo por el modo de Realidad Virtual. Jugado en unas Samsung Odyssey Plus.

Es una conversi√≥n b√°sica, estilo Skyrim VR (mundo en 3D pero interfaz en 2D, y manejo ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• gamepad) pero se juega bastante bien.
Es muy espectacular recorrer las mazmorras en 3D y a tama√±o real, especialmente los combates ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• enemigos de 3 metros de altura y espectaculares efectos especiales.

Lo √∫nico que se echa en falta es poder configurar las opciones gr√°ficas. Imprescindible jugar ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• al menos un supersampling de 300% para que no se vea borroso. No exige mucho equipo, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• mi GTX 1070 le meto 400% de supersampling y funciona perfectamente.

Buen juego de rol por turnos que es a√∫n m√°s espectacular en realidad virtual. Recomendado.

Very nice dungeon crawler if you want to scratch that itch.
Nice story and ambience.
Cool companions.
Combat is quite interesting and on the easy side (fewer enemies than I would like).

Overall it's really good game and made by a small studio, which is impressive regarding quality.

This game is fun. Graphic is beautiful. Gameplay is full turn-base and have depth of skill play than Legend of Grimrock. Those who love this kind of game should try it.

0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
32.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 20 f√©vrier 2022
Loved this game, after playing for only a few minutes i couldn't stop until i got 100% completation, your party chat a lot and they give you very useful information, even tips on how to solve the puzzle sometimes, the characters have great personality and the voices are great, the male main character sound smug as hell, i loved it.

The combat was just my kind of thing, turn based with all characters being mostly unique, enemies can give you quite a good challenge at parts, and the graphics are just beautiful, the world tree level is one of the most pretty stages i've seen in these dungeon crawler games, too bad my GPU couldn't handle everything at maximum.

I had only one thing that i didn't liked as much, the puzzles were way too many and mandatory, some were easy but others took me more time than i would've liked (that dragon puzzle at the last dungeon, jesus). I didn't have much trouble since i managed to find quite helpful guides here on steam and youtube videos, but i can imagine that a lot of people who played when the game came out got very frustrated.

If they ever were to make a sequel, it would be great if they cut off 80% of the puzzles, or put the puzzles for sidequests while having the main story be more straight foward, just like in Might and Magic X, that way people can just finish the story if they don't want to deal with that.

Even so, i enjoyed the game a lot, i hope to play again someday in VR, and i really hope they put out a sequel, preferable with the same character and beautiful art style.

9.5/10 for me, highly recommend it, but i really think you should use a guide, trueachievements covered the whole game and carried me through everything.
 
Kayderim
0
4 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
1
Non recommand√©
68.5 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 22 novembre 2020
I was on the fence when I first played the game. One has to get used to some of the mechanics such as energy (needed for special attacks) doesn't really increase unless you use a "guard" or rest at a camp (which requires wood).

Character creation: do a mage. - don't even consider not doing this. there is no real TRUE mage as companion found later in the game and they only come toward the end.

Puzzles are ok , loot is good - always something to upgrade but semi confusing. They have a system where it tells you how it impacts your offense, defense or magic - and for some reason it will list an agility item boost my attack much better for my fighter -- which I would have thought strength would have done this.

Battles are a lot of luck. Example: a few you go against a pretty hard mob(lots of hp / resistances) that will re-spawn other monsters to help - if one of those are a healer -and you are up against a very hefty monster with a lot of hp you are done - you cannot - wipe - restart. Want to target the healer first you say? Most likely you cannot if a monster uses taunt and forces you to attack a specific monster that just taunted. Golems come to mind here when you hit them (they have a few hundred hp - and your dmg is 2 - 5 per hit).

Attacking: numbers are typically very low numbers - it's like you are throwing spitballs at them.

Puzzles: most are ok - some are insane (thinking of a trial that has completely random tiles being zapped that you will fall through. You have to navigate a 10x3 or 4 grid and get to the other side - and the tiles which disappear has no pattern at all. Fall in and you are back to square one. Google this and see how many frustrated players are out there voicing how they have uninstalled the game because of this puzzle. the developers apparently seeing this decided to make it easier and say if the game shows you keep falling they will add another second before the tiles disappear LMFAO. My advice actually make it have a pattern that the typical person may be able to determine.

Stats: confusing in a way. The typical stats toward certain classes you are used to - well not so much here.

Initiative: seems like the monsters you will fight will always have more than you.

Monster Resists: i have never yet had a silence spell work on any monster. It says it does - but they cast w/o any issues.

There are areas in each dungeon you cannot access yet. I am on the fence with this mechanic. On one hand I am wondering did i miss something - only to find out (after using google) it will require an ability I get much later in the game. Game makers want us to think through these dungeons - but put in this type of mechanic which forces us to go online to discover after hours of searching and thinking something can't be done yet.

The worst and this imo is the biggest sin of any game maker - is making the final battle way over the top difficult to the point of FRUSTRATION. You invest hours into a game to just reach a point where it's so frustrating the game brings no enjoyment. That is the end battle.

The last battle is a human that turns into a dragon that then makes you fight portals which continually produce more monsters unless you kill the portal which you can only do if you kill the monsters fast enough - and then the dragon comes back - i stopped at this point my guys had only 10 - 30% hp left no energy and i was no where closer to ending this while doing this you you only have very limited potions, energy and health. (no wonder why there are many cheat engines for this game).

There is also a fixed number of encounters in the game so you cannot hope to get more levels and make it easier. I made it to lvl 22 - have all secrets, chests, keys from every level - others say you need to get to level 24 for the final battle - I wish I could but i can't find any other ways to get additional experience.

Another game that doesn't get finished!


 
gjhall99
0
8 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante

Non recommand√©
10.9 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 29 juin 2020
Produit rembours√©

Veteran dungeon Crawler here. Lets keep this simple the game sucks, but it has VR support which does add alot to the game visually. Sitting in bed layed back in VR dungeon crawling is pretty dope.

Positives:
-VR Mode !
-High Polish
-Nice Graphics
-Voice acting is well done.


Negatives:
- Bare bones character creation, only 3 classes and very little choice.
- Way Too many puzzles. Slows the game down.
- The Prologue was only annoying, Had to race to get to character creation.
- Lack of variety to character creation eliminates any replay value.

VR support is the only reason to pick this up.
Better games: Grimrock 2, Bards Tale 4, M&M Legacy.
 
wetro
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
4.1 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 24 octobre 2023
Produit re√ßu gratuitement

Sorry, but absolutely not. The exploration is okay, if a bit basic, but the combat is a miserable slog. Everything has way too much HP and will grind you down through slow, tedious battles of attrition. You can speed things up a small amount with skills, but they have long cooldowns, and use tons of energy, so either you're going to be resting between nearly every battle, or dealing with not being able to use your skills most of the time. Not sure who balanced this game, but they're clearly incompetent. The story is okay, the puzzles are okay, but the combat takes a game that could be at least okay and make it utter trash. Skip this one.
 
naachan
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
4.4 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 23 novembre 2023
Somehow I got 39 out of 47 achievements unlocked despite never playing this game. Weird, right? Legit - bought it on sale, never played it before, and suddenly a bunch of saved games with 20 or so hours worth of time invested into them shows up. I don't know, I don't get it.
So anyway, I played this for the FIRST TIME - and it's a buggy MESS. Combat feels slow when it should be quick. You can save at campfires, but otherwise you only save IF YOU QUIT THE GAME.
I played for 4 hours and got stuck on the environment 3 different times.
The chatter from the party members (you start out solo, immediately gain 1 follower, then gain another on the next map, and apparently more later on) sounds and feels asinine.
Lastly, when you use mana (which pretty much is with everything, no joke) there is no way to recover it unless you defend for a round - which has a few round cooldown. The mechanics for combat don't do this game any favors.
I love dungeon crawlers, and this had the potential to be a great hidden gem, but I am walking away from this completely disappointed. If you get it on a deep sale (like it is right now) then it might be worth it, but otherwise, I would hard pass on this game.
 
Isalon

√âvaluation publi√©e le 19 septembre 2020
This looks like its totally awesome, and in 2D probably is a cool and fun game. But in VR it just sucks, you cant interact in any meaningful way. Who ever did the port to VR has not even learned the basics. IF you are getting this for VR experience like I did dont waste your money. The VR controls just are not there. I did not try with a gamepad so keep that in mind if you have one it might be worth while.

Grammozeka
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
30.7 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 12 avril 2020
Produit re√ßu gratuitement

First impressions: I've played my fill of grid based games from the old days of Eyes of the Beholder, Might and Magic, Wizardry and Stonekeep, etc. There are a lot of modern titles like Grimlock 1 and 2, The Fall of the Dungeon Guardians, Dungeon Of Dragon Knight and Vaporum that have got a lot of love from the Steam Community. Operenica fits right in. Good music and graphics with a little different grid based design that works well with the gameplay. I also liked at the beginning that besides turn based combat you would do a little more than just drop a stone on a lever or pull a switch. It's a breath of fresh air to start out finding an item to put out a fire or move multiple mirrors to create a beam. When you do get into fighting there's a lot of deadly options to choose from rather than your standard "slash" and the animations look good on screen. I'm looking forward to spending more time with the game and delve deeper into what else it offers. So far a lot of fun to be had. :)

Update - 3 hours in and I can say this one is a keeper! Top shelf audio throughout the game play, beautiful environnments, excellent music, very good level design with a little bit of retread if you want to go back later and get other goodies left behind. My only small gripe is that I would like to have seen more creativity with the level designs. At the beginning we had a nice puzzle adjusting the mirrors and it falls pretty flat in the variety of design back to level pulling and door unlocking. I really liked the underwater areas but there could have been some missed opportunities here as you could have had random small whirlpools that would move around and possibly strike the group or undercurrents that randomly pushed the characters a few grids off depleting their air, etc. All in all though it is still very, very good. The game is taking me back to the days of playing Lands of Lore. That's really the feeling I'm getting while playing and that's a great thing. :)

Newest update - 15 hours in and just finished Chapter 7. Very surprised that only 17% have completed it with game almost out for a month but the game just keeps getting better the further you go. I'm in the Copper Forest now and it is a beautiful steampunk like world. Very impressed with many of the levels because they have their own fresh and unique look so gameplay is constantly new on every level. Couldn't recommend this title enough. :)

Final update - Completed the game at 30 hours. For the most part I had a lot of fun playing it as stated above. The only problem I ran into was the Copper Forest. While one of the most beautiful areas it was also the most deadly. I found that against a party of 5 steam robots if you didn't strike them all well in the first round it would likely have deadly consequences for your party. There were other comments about this area in discussions and I think the difficulty, even on Easy, could have been lowered a little to help. For some reason this area is even harder than further levels and I wasn't the only one to notice this. I even took on 10,000 HP "BOB" and beat him pretty easily too. For those that do brave further and reach the end don't lose hope in the final battle. It's a little deceptive thinking how much HP you will have to take the dragon down when in reality it plays out a little differently and he can be beat. It took me about 3 times on Easy so it can be done. :) As of right now there's only 6.1% on Steam who beat the boss. If I can do it then you can too. :)
 
Midnight77
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
21.2 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 26 juin 2020
I've just finished the first area (castle) and I'm having a real blast.

The graphics are good, the music is great and combat is your standard turn base. (thank god for this, I was getting tired of dungeon crawlers with realtime combat where the only strategy is to sidestep)

Voice acting for certain characters were good but others not so and the story so far is somewhat interesting.

One thing I enjoy a lot though is the game plays perfectly with a gamepad. (I wish more dungeon crawlers had this feature).

ViRTuaLiZaTe
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
42.7 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 9 avril 2020
Yes, It's a dungeon crawler blobber. Is it good? Yes. Is it revolutionary? Not really.

In this rare genre, it's worth to play anything that comes out but no, its not the only reason to pick it up.

After playing most of current games from this genre I was surprised that devs managed to sneak in some new things. First of all, there is a backtracking to previously visited locations through "teleport". And there is a merchant. And team composition with four active members and 3 in backup so you can switch them back and forth, depending on the situation.

The turn based combat is just fine. Most blobbers are trying to solve the problem with hit and run tactics and this execution is really nice. On the other hand, besides tutorial a lot of things are unexplained. There are icons for the "elements" but I at some point I didnt really know what are Underground spells because the icon didnt tell me. Few skills simply didnt get to work. I was using correct weapon, on the correct line with correct attribute maxed and still didnt manage to deal more than 10 damage every single time - and I tried a lot.
And the mentioned attributes are a mess. There is no description of what does what really. Strenght boost physical attack but it also boots health. Same as Vigor. But Vigor doesnt add much else over it so I basically threw everything into one main damage stat for every characer and managed to get away with it rather easily.

While it might sound harsh, it didn't really kill my joy. I wouldnt bother about it but yeah - I would be happier without those issues.

The plot is fine. Some really cool moments and decent worldbuilding. I love this genre because all of those games, even bad ones are extremelly immersive. Maybe because of the first person view, maybe because of how the world is constructed. There was always this kind of enclosing and claustrophobic feeling. In Grimrock where you had to travel through Tower or Fall of Dungeon Guardians where you are climbing up from deep prison. Previously mentioned fast travel kind of killed it for me. It was fresh but I wouldnt cry without it.

But there is one thing that I absolutely loved. Little conversations that my characters had with each other. They were great, witty and funny. How the rogue guy was making fun of typical knight that didnt get how the sarcasm works. Or comments there were always dirrected to the fourth wall. Or comments about cliches in this genre - amazing!

My final rating is 7.5/10. Good job guys and I'm waiting for the next one!
 
Viveroth
248 produits enregistr√©s
0
Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
34.9 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 14 septembre 2020
I've just played for 8 hours but I feel I should leave a review here. I'm already noticing some of the bad things people complain about in this game, but it's not bad at all. You're gonna have a great experience playing, the only downside are the combat system: some encounters are super easy, other are quite unfair and unbalanced. Skills are not its strong point either, but it is an astonishing dungeon crawler: it mixes up a lot of puzzles (some harder than others) and secrets (and there's a bunch of them) with an incredible graphic design, hilarious dialogue from time to time, a quite good voice acting (ignoring the tutorial of course) and a very good story so far. I would recommend it, because even with its flaws it is a new and modern dungeon crawling experience with everything you would expect from an older one. I see Operencia as a big step forward to the optimisation of this genre to a modern gaming experience.
 
XyrasOnion
0
3 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
0.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 28 novembre 2020
Just to say, with no bearing on the quality of the game, the VR implementation makes me ill (I've logged a couple hunderd hours in VR games). The grid based movement follows your controller dpad, not your head, so pressing forward may take you in a different direction than where you're looking. You'll find yourself sliding and stopping as your character observes the grid based movement. Played about 20mins and I got hit by a wave of VR sickness.

I think the devs can allievate this by introducing more comfort and movement options and, which the game currently has none.

Lastly, the VR graphics are locked to one setting, which is quite modest.
 
spineduke
1,024 produits enregistr√©s
0
1 personne a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation amusante
1
Non recommand√©
36.2 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 16 septembre 2020
This isn't a solid no because the game is bad. Operencia is great as an old school throwback. It has puzzles, secrets, and isn't just an easy stroll in the park. These are all fine and would normally make me give a positive review, but I caution you.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!Why? The answer is simple.The end boss is absolutely stupid. Not just because it is ridiculously difficult (that too) but because it is extremely disappointing. You have to fight waves of minions instead of the main boss before you get to the boss, but wait! You also have to target something without a health bar that is ONLY damageable if you can dps rush while keeping yourself alive. Yes, it is extremely difficult. I don't think anything in wizardry, grimrock, or any other old school game comes close to this difficulty. All because you cannot target the object you need to attack until everything dies, and you have 5 turns to do so until they are all re-summoned or if you didn't kill them all more come. I cannot stress this enough. Do not buy this game! It is extremely good in all aspects, except for the end. But the end is sooooooo bad that is completely ruins it. If you don't think that a terrible ending ruins the game, and are willing to go through multiple 15-30 minute tries, then go for it. But this is just a warning to you all.
 
wizopizo
0
8 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
1
Non recommand√©
0.3 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 19 novembre 2020
Sorry to say that I can't recommend it, at least for VR play.

I was excited to see a VR RPG even though it's not really my preferred genre it looked like it would be a really cool VR experience.

I will say that the environments are gorgeous. but this is a 3D game in VR, not a VR game

it doesn't come with bindings or instructions to use the vive controllers. you have to use a separate, normal gaming controller. grid based movement. it's just not a virtual reality experience in any sense of the word.

if you want a nice 3D RPG experience with your VR setup maybe this is for you. I was looking for a true VR experience and this definitely isn't it
 
R0AR | gr3yh47

√âvaluation publi√©e le 20 octobre 2021
–ï—â—ë –æ–¥–∏–Ω –ø—Ä–æ–¥–æ–ª–∂–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å –¥–µ–ª–∞ Legend of Grimrock, –≤–µ—Ä–Ω—É–≤—à–µ–≥–æ –Ω–∞–º –ª–∞–º–ø–æ–≤—ã–µ –ø–æ–¥–∑–µ–º–µ–ª—å—è –∏ –±–µ–≥–∞–Ω—å–µ –ø–æ –∫–≤–∞–¥—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–∫–∞–º.
–ü—Ä–æ–¥–æ–ª–∂–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å –¥–æ–≤–æ–ª—å–Ω–æ —Å–∞–º–æ–±—ã—Ç–Ω—ã–π (–≤ –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–∏–µ, –Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, –æ—Ç –í–∞–ø–æ—Ä–∏—É–º–∞, –≤ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–º –≤—Å—ë –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–∏–µ —ç—Ç–æ –ø–æ —Å—É—Ç–∏ —Å—Ç–∏–º–ø–∞–Ω–∫–æ–≤—Å–∫–∏–π –º–∏—Ä). –î–∞, —Ç—É—Ç —Ç–æ–∂–µ –±–µ–≥–∞–Ω—å–µ –ø–æ –∫–≤–∞–¥—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–∫–∞–º, –Ω–æ —Å–∞–º–æ—É–±–∏—Ç—å—Å—è, —É–ø–∞–≤ –≤ —è–º—É —Å –ª–æ–≤—É—à–∫–æ–π –∏–ª–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–ø–∞—Å—Ç—å –Ω–µ–ª—å–∑—è (–æ—Ç—á–∞—Å—Ç–∏ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–µ –µ—Å—Ç—å, –Ω–æ —ç—Ç–æ –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–∂–∏—Ç—å), –Ω–µ–ª—å–∑—è –∏ –º–∞—Ö–∞—Ç—å –æ—Ä—É–∂–∏–µ–º –≤ –ª—é–±–æ–π –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç. –ë–æ–∏ —Ç—É—Ç –ø—Ä–æ–∏—Å—Ö–æ–¥—è—Ç –≤ –ø–æ—à–∞–≥–æ–≤–æ–º —Ä–µ–∂–∏–º–µ –Ω–∞ –æ—Ç–¥–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ –∑–∞–≥—Ä—É–∂–∞–µ–º–æ–π –∞—Ä–µ–Ω–µ, –≥–¥–µ –¥–µ–π—Å—Ç–≤—É—é—â–∏–µ –º–æ—Ä–¥—ã –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ –æ–±–º–µ–Ω–∏–≤–∞—é—Ç—Å—è —É–¥–∞—Ä–∞–º–∏, –ø—Ä–∏—ë–º–∞–º–∏, –ø—å—é—Ç –∑–µ–ª—å—è –∏ –≤–æ—Ç —ç—Ç–æ –≤–æ—Ç –≤—Å—ë, –±–µ–∑ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–¥–≤–∏–∂–µ–Ω–∏—è. –ë–æ–∏ —Å—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–µ–Ω—å–∫–∏–µ, –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –¥–æ–ª–≥–∏–µ –Ω–∞ –º–æ–π –≤–∑–≥–ª—è–¥, –Ω–æ –∏ –Ω–µ —Å–∫–∞–∑–∞—Ç—å —á—Ç–æ –ø–ª–æ—Ö–∏–µ. –ö–∞–∫ –∏ —Ä–æ–ª–µ–≤–∞—è —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º–∞. –í–ø–æ–ª–Ω–µ —Å–µ–±–µ –µ—Å—Ç—å –æ —á—ë–º –≤ –Ω–µ–π –ø–æ–¥—É–º–∞—Ç—å, –Ω–æ –∑–≤—ë–∑–¥ —Å –Ω–µ–±–∞ –Ω–µ —Ö–≤–∞—Ç–∞–µ—Ç.
–ì–µ—Ä–æ–π —É –Ω–∞—Å –æ–¥–∏–Ω, –º—ã –µ–≥–æ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞—ë–º —Å –Ω—É–ª—è, –Ω–æ –ø–æ—Å—Ç–µ–ø–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –∫ –Ω–∞–º –ø—Ä–∏—Å–æ–µ–¥–∏–Ω—è—Ç—Å—è –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–µ –∫–æ–ª–æ—Ä–∏—Ç–Ω—ã–µ –ª–∏—á–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏, —á–∞—Å—Ç—å –∏–∑ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã—Ö –≤–æ–æ–±—â–µ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç —Ö–æ—Ç—å —Å –Ω–∞–º–∏ –≤ –∫–∞—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–¥–≤–∏–∂–Ω–æ–≥–æ —Ç–æ—Ä–≥–æ–≤—Ü–∞. –° —Å–æ–±–æ–π –º—ã —Å–º–æ–∂–µ–º (–ø–æ–º–∏–º–æ –≥–ª–∞–≤–≥–µ—Ä–æ—è) –≤–∑—è—Ç—å —Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ö –∏–∑ —Å–µ–º–∏ –Ω–∞ –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä.
–°—é–∂–µ—Ç –æ—Ç–Ω–æ—Å–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ –ª–∏–Ω–µ–µ–Ω, –Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–π–¥–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –º–µ—Å—Ç–∞ –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç –∏ –Ω—É–∂–Ω–æ –±—É–¥–µ—Ç –≤–µ—Ä–Ω—É—Ç—å—Å—è. –¢—É—Ç –µ—Å—Ç—å —á—Ç–æ-—Ç–æ —Ç–∏–ø–∞ –Ω–∞–≤—ã–∫–æ–≤, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–µ –æ—Ç–∫—Ä—ã–≤–∞—é—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –ø—Ä–æ—Ç—è–∂–µ–Ω–∏–∏ –≤—Å–µ–π –∏–≥—Ä—ã. –ù–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, –ª–æ–ø–∞—Ç–∞, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–π –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –∫–æ–ø–∞—Ç—å –∫–ª–∞–¥ –∏–ª–∏ –º–æ–ª–æ—Ç, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π –≤–æ—Å—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–∞–≤–ª–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –∫–∞–º–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –º–æ—Å—Ç–∏–∫–∏. –¢–∞–∫ –∂–µ –ø–æ–ª–Ω–æ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω—ã—Ö —Å–µ–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–æ–≤, –≤ —Ç–æ–º —á–∏—Å–ª–µ –∏ —Å–∏–ª—å–Ω–æ —Å–µ–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–Ω—ã—Ö, –Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, –∫–ª—é—á –¥–ª—è —Å–µ–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–∞ –∏–∑ –ø–µ—Ä–≤–æ–≥–æ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω—è –º—ã –ø–æ–ª—É—á–∏–º —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –Ω–∞ —Å–∞–º–æ–º –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ–¥–Ω–µ–º.
–ú–∏—Ä –∏–≥—Ä—ã –¥–∞–∂–µ –Ω–µ —Ñ–µ–Ω—Ç–µ–∑–∏–π–Ω—ã–π, –∞ –æ—Ç–∫—Ä–æ–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–æ —Å–∫–∞–∑–æ—á–Ω—ã–π. –ü—Ä–∏—á—ë–º —è–≤–Ω–æ –Ω–∞–º–µ—à–∞–Ω–æ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ –≤—Å–µ–≥–æ, —Ç—É—Ç –∏ –ø—Ä–æ–∫–ª—è—Ç—ã–µ –ø–æ –≤—Å—è–∫–æ–º—É –∑–∞–º–∫–∏ –Ω–∞ –∫–∞–∂–¥–æ–º —à–∞–≥—É –∏ –±–æ–±–æ–≤—ã–µ —Å—Ç–µ–±–ª–∏ –∏ –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ–µ –¥—Ä—É–≥–æ–µ. –ê –≤—Ä–∞–≥ —É –Ω–∞—Å –≤–æ–æ–±—â–µ –¥—Ä–∞–∫–æ–Ω. –¢—Ä—ë—Ö–≥–æ–ª–æ–≤—ã–π. –ë—Ä–∞—Ç–∞ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–≥–æ —É–±–∏–ª –ê—Ç–∏–ª–ª–∞.
–û–¥–Ω–æ–π –∏–∑ –≥–ª–∞–≤–Ω—ã—Ö —Å–∏–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö –∏ –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω—ã—Ö —á–µ—Ä—Ç —è–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ç–æ, —á—Ç–æ —ç—Ç–æ –Ω–µ –æ—á–µ—Ä–µ–¥–Ω–∞—è –±–∞—à–Ω—è (—Å—Ç–æ—è—á–∞—è –∏–ª–∏ –ø–æ–¥ –∑–µ–º–ª—ë–π), –∞ –º–Ω–æ–≥–æ –æ—á–µ–Ω—å —Ä–∞–∑–Ω–æ–æ–±—Ä–∞–∑–Ω—ã—Ö –∏ —à–∏–∫–∞—Ä–Ω–æ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞–Ω–Ω—ã—Ö —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω–µ–π. –ü–æ–ª—É–∑–∞—Ç–æ–ø–ª–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –ø—Ä–æ–∫–ª—è—Ç—ã–π –∑–∞–º–æ–∫, –≥–¥–µ –≤–æ–¥–∞ —Ç–µ—á—ë—Ç –ø–æ –ø–æ—Ç–æ–ª–∫—É, —Ç—ë–º–Ω—ã–π –ª–µ—Å, —Ä–∞–∑—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–π –ø–∞—Ä—è—â–∏–π –∑–∞–º–æ–∫, –º–µ–¥–Ω—ã–π –ª–µ—Å (–±—É–∫–≤–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ!) –∏ –¥—Ä—É–≥–∏–µ –ø–æ–¥—á–∞—Å –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –æ—Ä–∏–≥–∏–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–µ —É—Ä–æ–≤–Ω–∏. –î–∞, –º–æ–¥–µ–ª—å–∫–∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–µ–Ω—å–∫–∏–µ, –Ω–æ –∞–≤—Ç–æ—Ä—ã —Å–º–æ–≥–ª–∏ —Å–¥–µ–ª–∞—Ç—å –æ—á–µ–Ω—å –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤–æ, –∞ –º–µ—Å—Ç–∞–º–∏ –¥–∞–∂–µ –æ—Ä–∏–≥–∏–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ. –ö—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤–∞—è —Å–∏–º—Ñ–æ–Ω–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∞—è –º—É–∑—ã–∫–∞ —Å–∫—Ä–∞—à–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –∞—Ç–º–æ—Å—Ñ–µ—Ä—É.
–ü–µ—Ä—Å–æ–Ω–∞–∂–∏ –¥–∞ –∏ —Å—é–∂–µ—Ç –≤ —Ü–µ–ª–æ–º –Ω–µ –æ—Ç—Å—Ç–∞—é—Ç –∏ —è–≤–ª—è—é—Ç—Å—è –ª—É—á—à–µ–π —á–∞—Å—Ç—å—é –∏–≥—Ä—ã. –ò–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω—ã–µ —Ç–∏–ø–∞–∂–∏, –ø–æ–¥—á–∞—Å –¥–∞–∂–µ –Ω–µ –∑–∞–µ–∑–∂–µ–Ω–Ω—ã–µ (–∫—Ä–æ–º–µ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–π –ø–æ–ø—ã—Ç–∫–∏ –≤ –ø–æ–≤–µ—Å—Ç–æ—á–∫—É, –æ—Ç–∫—Ä–æ–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –∂–∞–ª–∫–æ–π –∏ –∏–¥–∏–æ—Ç—Å–∫–æ–π, –Ω—É, –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞, –≤–ø—Ä–æ—á–µ–º), –±–∞–ª–∞–≥—É—Ä—è—â–∏–µ (–¥–∞–∂–µ —É–¥–∞—á–Ω–æ) –¥—Ä—É–≥ –Ω–∞–¥ –¥—Ä—É–≥–æ–º –∏ –æ–∫—Ä—É–∂–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º –Ω–∞ –∫–∞–∂–¥–æ–º —à–∞–≥—É.
–í —Ü–µ–ª–æ–º –ø–æ–ª—É—á–∏–ª–æ—Å—å –ø—É—Å—Ç—å –∏ –Ω–µ –±–µ–∑ –Ω–µ–¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–∫–æ–≤, –Ω–æ —Ö–æ—Ä–æ—à–µ–µ –≤–µ—Å—ë–ª–æ–µ –∏ —Å–∫–∞–∑–æ—á–Ω–æ–µ –ø—Ä–∏–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Å –∫—É—á–µ–π —Å–µ–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–æ–≤, –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–µ–Ω—å–∫–∏–º–∏ –≥–æ–ª–æ–≤–æ–ª–æ–º–∫–∞–º–∏, –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–Ω—ã–º–∏ –≤–∏–¥–∞–º–∏ –∏ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω—ã–º –≥–µ–π–º–ø–ª–µ–µ–º.

Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
3.9 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 10 mai 2020
Produit re√ßu gratuitement

Are you a RPG fan, and do you like turn based combat, that is also a dungeon crawler, whilst exploring multiple levels, with a deep story? Then buckle up because Zen studios has released Operencia, the stolen sun, an amazing mix of story with all the rest of elements mentioned above. But do you want more of an in dept review of what this gorgeous game has to offer, then I will be more then pleased to tell you our experience!

What we liked:
The general story: without going too in dept about this, there is an amazing story line behind the game. All throughout the different quests / levels, you experience your team telling you more about why they do certain things, and just generally interesting dialogues between them. This mixed together with other elements like narrators, makes it feel like a fairy tale you are experiencing first hand
The music and sound effects: Zen studios has really gone out of their way to add the most complete sound design to a RPG game which I played in the last year. The music has a nice calm mood to it, that adds to the mythical experience all throughout, whilst certain basements / castle levels have a more mysterious vibe to them. Overall an experience to remember.

The graphics and scaling: This game has amazing artwork packed into a complete overall package. Zen studio‚Äôs also nailed the fact that it supports 21:9 aspect ratio for a more immersive experience! The characters are custom drawn, every level has more and more different artwork, and the scenes are overall gorgeous to view and stair upon.
The combat: In this game during your turn based fighting system, there is a surprising amount of dept that is linked to it. The game has a mana system that only allows you to cast certain spells for a certain amount of time, and if you want to regain mana during a fight, there is a tool, but that skips the combat for that character for that round, overall a good system!
The difficulty options: this game allows you to choose how hard you want specific elements of the game to be, and all throughout the saving spots, it gives you the opportunity to modify those parameters in case you feel like it was too simple for you. A great touch that more developers should implement in my opinion!

What we had mixed feelings about:
Pc support: this game is a clear example of super great game but that has been made to support a controller. On mouse and keyboard, the gameplay felt a little odd. For example, having to define multiple keys to turn your head, whilst also only being allowed to move left right, and forward. But after about a level or so, I connected my controller, and it started to feel a lot more as it should, rather smooth and intuitive gameplay. The only remark I have about this is that I found myself making movements, and running against walls, because I am used to the fact that I can move freely and diagonally, but after getting used to the tile movement system, this was not really an issue anymore.

What we didn‚Äôt like: to be honest nothing..

Overall impression: this game from Zen studios really shook up my perception about turn based combat and dungeon crawlers in generally. I was blown away by the gameplay, smoothness, and quest lines, all whilst being hooked to my pc screen to continue playing. For which I grant them a solid 95% score. As mentioned above, the only point I wish I had seen was that I could play it with mouse and keyboard, but then again, being able to lay on your bed whilst playing this gorgeous game is also just an experience to have!


Want more reviews like this?
Check us out on lifeisxbox.eu!
 
xendacine

√âvaluation publi√©e le 16 janvier 2021
Design et ambiance magiques, une histoire, un syst√®me de combat tour par tour tactique, le cot√© RPG "old school" case par case avec une touche de modernit√©, des √©nigmes pas si compliqu√©es que cel√† (mais quand m√™me un peu). Bref, c'est excellent et je r√©clame √† tout amateur du genre, a noter qu'il vous faudra vous munir de patience, d'une bonne acuit√© ainsi qu'une disponibilit√© d'esprit !

Recommand√©
15.8 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 30 avril 2021
Puzzles: The Game

What I Liked

Not many games like this come out now a days. I hesitated on this purchase for awhile and finally did it when I wanted something like this to play. The graphics were great and combat was a lot of fun. Each area has its own look. Choices on how to build a character matter so much. The story was decent enough.

What I Did Not Like

The puzzles. I never get why games like this have to have puzzles. Some were downright frustrating, while others I had to look up online to find the answer.

Why I Stopped Playing

I stopped because I got tired of the puzzles. I just don't like puzzles. I was hoping they would be simple, but they aren't.

If you like these kind of games, especially the puzzle part of the game, then I say go for it. It just wasn't for me in the end.

Disclaimer

I have been a gamer for over 30 years. I tend to play mostly PC games. I also bounce around between games A LOT. I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it. Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad. It just means another game caught my attention. I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things. Keep that in mind when reading my reviews. If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!
 
Roan Woasbi

√âvaluation publi√©e le 14 septembre 2021
Don't let the great visual and audio design fool you. Under the surface is a completely inflexible and tedious dungeon crawl with pathetic dialogues.

Even more than a year I still regret wasting money on this game. (And it wasn't even much)
 
Level 1 Commoner

Personne n'a trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
7.5 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 4 janvier 2023
Beautyful artwork, sound-design, and excelent storytelling full of folklore and fantasy. Very good map design, inventory system and HUD.

While the character system is deep it's also convoluted and poorly explained.

Hit chance is brutal and brakes the game battle-system disfavouring the player, it constantly appears to be out of control in sheer randomness.

Key itens constantly hidden by secrets or poorly highlighted not respecting player's time. (got stuck on the star relic in the royal tomb far too long.)

What was the purpose of tile movement? Aside for some traps It doesn't serve any mechanic in the game.

2 times got a glitch where i was stuck in the wall and could not move.

I don't recommend the game.
 
TGG Shaka
0
2 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Recommand√©
46.5 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 6 septembre 2022
Absolutely amazing RPG game, 9.5/10.

This game has an incredible atmosphere and story, interesting characters with great speech... basically it shows you what Legend of Grimrock could have been with a full story like this game!
The story is very unusual, but it feels alive and is fascinating... the gaphics and music are great and let you dive into this word of fantasy... the humor is spot on... sarcastic, funny... a real blast!
The game has a lot of levels/environments, it took me 46h to complete on Normal, secrets, many puzzles which deserve the name, quite difficult enemies sometimes... several special skills which make the game a bit metroidvania.

The story and banter between the characters is definitely the best of the game... I will miss that party of different characters.
So why not 10/10? A few battles were too hard to early (Reka the queen...), some puzzles are too hard/not enough info, and the game doesnt close once you quit, I needed to Ctr-Alt Del it... but this are all minor things, as this game was a true experience which is rare... it brought me to a different world. Highly recommended!
 
Adrian
0

√âvaluation publi√©e le 21 juin 2021
TL,DR OVERALL RATING: 7.5/10 if you like RPGs of this style, maybe 6/10 if you're just a fan of RPGs in general. I'm writing this immediately after finishing my first playthrough and am already planning to start a second with some of the hard-mode options on.

If you enjoy other grid-based first-person dungeon crawlers (such as Legend of Grimrock, Vaporum, Might and Magic Legacy, etc), definitely give this game a look. Perhaps look for a sale if you're on the fence, but I'd wager that you'll enjoy Operencia well enough if you got a lot of playtime out of games like the ones listed above.

The environments look very nice, and are quite varied in feel. You won't be suffering from Grimrock 1's "oh look, more floor to ceiling stone walls" mindset. The sound design wasn't spectacular, but didn't offend me any...I mostly didn't notice it much.

The dialog can be a little unnatural feeling, and the voice acting would be decent for early 2000s but is not up to par for today's standards. I ended up skipping a lot of the voice acting by mid game or so.

The story (as far as I gather) is drawn extensively from Hungarian mythology. It wasn't terribly compelling to me, but it was interesting at the least. If you can at least enjoy hearing about foreign mythologies, you'll probably be entertained enough at this story to keep going.

The combat and character build mechanics took a little while for me to get used to and figure out how to optimize. This was probably my biggest draw to keep going with the game, which is typical for me as I'm very heavily a mechanics-driven gamer. There's 5 main stats you can increase, an an entire page of sub-stats that these main stats have effects on. It can take a bit of experimenting to pin down how important each of these things are, and how to approach each character's build based on their available skill trees.

With that all said though, a HUGE boon to this game is that you can respec any characters stats or skill trees at any time (outside of combat) with no cost. Your fire mage hits an area with heavily fire resistant enemies? Pop 'em over to the lightning tree for a while! Realize that Joska's starting investment of agility doesn't really fit his skill trees of mostly strength and intelligence skills? Pull those points out and make him more potent in the areas where he shines! I did a decent amount of respeccing until I came up with builds that worked well for me (especially with one specific character later in the game who is just awkward to build).

Unfortunately, the menus can be a little unwieldy (especially in VR) and the inventory management annoyed me quite a bit. I think there were a few too many items that were too similar that end up cluttering up your inventory. Plus you don't get access to a vendor to unload stuff you don't want for longer than I would have liked. At the very least, you can always buy back items you've sold in case you find a use for one of these side-grade items later on. And money never presented any major concern for me.

Another minor draw is the VR support for the game. I only played maybe a couple hours of my first playthrough in VR, but it was definitely a neat experience. Being able to look around the gorgeous environments and actually see everything all around you is pretty fantastic. However, I felt like the controls for the menus in particular were very detrimental to actually playing through the whole game in VR. With the amount of time I spent fiddling with builds and stats and gear, I can't imagine having done all that through the VR controls and still enjoying myself. I don't know if I would recommend this game to play entirely in VR, but if you happen to have the capability already, definitely give it a try for a little while.
 
The Living Noise
0

√âvaluation publi√©e le 2 juillet 2021
STOP:
Are you playing as a Mage? No? Then restart the game and completely ignore the Ranger and Barbarian types. You'll never beat the game with those two. You're being stubborn? Fine, read the review below to find out more about the frustration that is this game if you aren't using the spellcaster:

This game is entirely too difficult and I'm playing it on the easiest setting. I've tried every setup I can imagine between my characters, stats, skills, and gear and still can't get past the third area's boss. Not only have I tried, but two of my friends have completely redone my setup as well, with no success. I had to fight each of the "bosses" I've come across more than ten times each before finally getting lucky enough to beat them. There isn't any skill to it; just luck.
The characters are so completely "balanced" as to be useless; there's no tank, healer, fighter, etc. They are all middle of the road Jack of All Trades who are just "Meh" at every skill set with no possible way of making them better. If I could go back to previous areas and rebattle monsters to increase my levels, at least then I'd be able to advance in the game, but now I'm super p****ed at myself for wasting money on something I'll never be able to complete.
 
Sparrowulf

√âvaluation publi√©e le 19 septembre 2020
Playing only in VR. On the Vive. Control bindings are available on steam. But it's just emulating the gamepad.

The art and music is gorgeous and everything is really polished. The graphics in VR are about like Vanishing Realms. Maybe a little better. Enemies definitely look better.

The combat feels good in VR. Even though you can't see your hands and it's just menu navigation.
You do see some FX when you get hit. Feels pretty normal though for the type of game it is. Turn based RPG so you won't be doing too much with your hands anyway.
Doesn't hurt the immersion too much.

Gameplay itself is very old school RPG. If you've played Entrian Oddyssey it sort of reminds me of that game. Heavy on mapping. It's tile based so you can traverse the entire level while only looking at the map.

There aren't too many RPGs in VR and this is one is pretty good.
 
droneattack

Recommand√©
1.6 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 2 avril 2020
Produit re√ßu gratuitement

"New first-person dungeon crawlers are pretty rare in general nowadays, and I'm glad to say that Operencia really does the genre proud!"

To put it in gaming terms, Operencia: The Stolen Sun is a grid-based, old-school-style first-person dungeon crawler with an interesting, though not entirely unique, turn-based combat that emphasizes on tackling enemies based on the rows they are on, whether they are in front, middle or at the back. There are some pretty devious puzzles to solve; some epic dragon slaying to do, and an engaging story about defeating the creatures of the Underworld that are just spilling out onto the surface and sending them back to where the belong!

Despite having a historical/mythical theme, I also really like that the game doesn't just use the typical, well-known stuff. Instead, you'll get to "meet" historical figures (with a dab of fantasy) like Attila the Hun as well as mythical heroes from lesser known legends. After all, a game doesn't always have to be about "King Arthur" or "Alexander the Great" to be great.

For someone who isn't very familiar with dungeon crawlers of this format, however, I personally find some of the puzzles in this game to be rather tricky. Quick tip - make sure to interact with torches Maybe this is just me though!

Watch me play!
Vid√©o YouTube‚Ñ¢: TheMidcoreGamer Plays Operencia: The Stolen Sun (No Commentary Gameplay) 
Vues : 34
Operencia: The Stolen Sun is a grid-based, old-school-style first-person dungeon crawler with an interesting, though not entirely unique, turn-based combat that emphasizes on tackling enemies based...

- I got stuck at a puzzle in this vid but I found the solution not long after... because guides! :P Will make a part 2 then!
- Also, note that although there's a bit of a stutter while streaming, the game worked great and smooth on my end.

Pros
+ Devious puzzles - make sure to check everything, making sure you don't miss anything that you can interact with.
+ Strategic turn-based combat. You can get a nice "Ambush" advantage just by approaching an enemy from the sides or the back and the different rows where enemies are positioned (front, center or back) really changes how you build/develop your characters' skills. You'll want to have a team that has skill sets that provide a nice coverage of all three rows.
+ Good voice acting that can sometimes be rather heavily accented.
+ Really nice graphics, especially the art during cutscenes and the underwater dungeon!
+ I enjoyed the story a lot so far, especially the good-humoured banter between Attila and his queen.
+ Lots of secret loot to find - make sure to explore every room/grid!
+ The first-person dungeon crawlers that I've played has really rigid movements whereas this is not the case here. However, it does feel weird to be able to move along the grids so quickly - can be a bit dizzy sometimes. Works great when you're trying to ambush an enemy.
+ Considering the hours you can get out of this game, the game is well-priced. Worth getting the game at full price but if money's a bit tight for you because of the virus, you can always add the game in your wishlist and check back in when there's a sale.

‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•/Feedback
- The game crashed at the end of my stream. Not sure what happened though!

Overall
Operencia: The Stolen Sun may not be everyone's cup of tea but it's definitely an old-school-like dungeon crawler that's worth playing. The game's gorgeous as they go, and it does have really great writing. Being a fan of turn-based strategy games AND dungeon crawlers (though I usually prefer dungeon crawlers/action RPGs like Grim Dawn, Diablo, Torchlight, Path of Exile, etc), I love how the game uses row-positioning to ramp up the challenge a bit, making combat feels "fresh" and different.

So, my verdict? Operencia may be an indie game; it's incredibly well-polished and it's fun! Buy it and play it if you love first-person dungeon crawlers or turn-based RPGs.


Side Note
If you like this review and would like to follow me for more, please feel free to drop by my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33780629-The-Midcore-Gamer/
 
Arion

√âvaluation publi√©e le 26 avril 2020
Looks great.
Sounds good.
Voice acting is pretty good.
Plays ok.
Encounters...... well the only way i can describe it is OBNOXIOUS to the point of INFURIATING!
So this is my experience of fighting some dead wizard lady.
The enemies can block you, ok yeah fine then the enemies taunt you leaving you with only 1 option to target, then the d**k whos taunting you will stop and attack you letting his oppo take over the taunting while he attacks all the while you're getting bombarded by some undead bird.
when you EVENTUALLY BEAT THE 2 B*****DS you'll have a couple turns in which you can attack her and then SHE'LL PUT UP A SHIELD and after that she'll SUMMON 2 MORE (she constantly spawns new skeletons in to replace the dead ones) ENEMIES that will again taunt and attack you.
By this point you've run out of magic (unless you have 2 yes 2 POTIONS) so you're expected to beat this bony b***h with nothing but harsh words and a few slaps with a crappy sword or a few pokes with arrows.
Also there's the fact that the lady with no pulse or skin NEVER RUNS OUT OF MAGIC!
But you can bet your pay check that you ran out of magic maybe 10 minutes ago.
Oh i forgot to mention that this particular skinless c**k womble comes after you've beaten 4 hard as nails undead that are basically carbon copies of your team PLUS A MAGE THAT YOU DON'T HAVE BECAUSE UNLESS YOU START THE GAME YOU WONT COME ACROSS 1!!!

Again this game is f*****g obnoxious and needlessly difficult.

It has potential but in the state its in don't waste your money.
Play Legend of Grimrock instead its a MUCH better game.

√âvaluation publi√©e le 21 septembre 2020
I love blobbers. That being said, I kind of hate this game. I don't mind premade characters, but I do mind when they babble endlessly about how SUPER DUPER POWUHFUL they are, like 7 year olds playing with action figures, all while treating you as if you are the idiot in the room. "MY GUY HAS A DEMON IN HIS SUPER HAMMER! OH YEAH? WELL MY GUY IS A KINGSLAYER!" And while that idiotic babble about how everyone you run into happens to be a superhero who know all the kings and queens and gods and whatever isn't screeching in your ear , they're screaming at you about how to solve every puzzle you come across. "GEE, LOOK AT THAT. IT'S A HOLE. IT LOOKS LIKE A HOLE FOR A GEAR. THERE MUST BE A GEAR AROUND HERE." Then, later, "I WONDER WHAT THIS GEAR IS FOR. I KNOW! THIS MUST GO TO THE THING YOU SAW EARLIER! WHAT IF YOU TURN IT CLOCKWISE! OH BOY, THAT DID IT!"

Kinda defeats the purpose of having a puzzle, no?

Also, whenever they'e happy about something, they say, "Alas! What a good day!" Like... what? That's not what "alas" means.

Oh, and the art design. God, don't get me started. The short version is that their company is very clearly cynical as hell, has no interest in cultivating any kind of aesthetic that could be described as something other than "marketable pap for idiot children." It looks like WoW. Yeah. It's hideous.

All I could think throughout my entire playtime was, "God. Shut up. Why won't they shut up? Who WROTE this trash? Oh look, another treasure chest full of so much money and ugly looking crap that I'll never want for anything. Why even have money in this game?"

As for the combat: I play on the hardest setting and could pretty much just tie a blindfold around my face and click randomly and win. It's so dumb.

Perhaps I am the idiot for buying this game and not refunding it after all.

If it weren't for the writing I'd give this game a "meh" 4/10. Given how childish and idiotic it is, mixed with the awful aesthetic, I give this a 2/10. It's so stupid. SO stupid.

Avoid. Do not buy. This is not the blobber you want. There is nothing interesting, innovative, or fun here.
 
troika
0
4 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile
0
Non recommand√©
0.7 h en tout
√âvaluation publi√©e le 12 juillet 2021
This game lets you pick whether the single character you can create is a Warrior, Ranger, or Sorcerer.

I had to return the game for that reason. It's just entirely too basic to be entertaining. I expected to create a party with a variety of classes that could fill different roles. I expected something that improved on Eye of the Beholder.

Instead, most of your party will always consist of NPCs. With only three classes in total, each of which fills a required role in combat, there are only a few viable party compositions.

Maybe it was designed first as a VR game and mouse-and-keyboard play was secondary. Maybe it's targeted at a young audience despite taking an archaic grid-based approach to dungeon crawling. Whatever the cause, there's nothing to plan around or customize. Each class has a talent tree, but each rung has an obvious best choice, which is no choice at all.

If you're in it for the story rather than the gameplay, Operencia has a striking visual style and an interesting world, but it's a mile wide and an inch deep.
 
Hart
0
4 personnes ont trouv√© cette √©valuation utile

After playing Operencia for just over an hour I could tell it wasn't for me. Everything is poorly done - the tutorial is uninformative and confusing. The voice acting, which I generally don't care about, is cringe worthy. The combat isn't interesting or enjoyable.
